climbs.name: Queen's Keep
climbs.fa: Dakota Walz, James Menez, & Jean François May 2015

content.description: Queen's Keep traverses left along a crack below an overhang. It straightens out a bit before dodging a bush by escaping right ending at the top of the formation. This was done on-sight and ground up so I'm certain the state we left it in would still make it a dangerous climb. We must have left a sling at the top to get down or hiked off. Definitely no bolts added though. Potential sport climbs around and through it may be more worthy.
content.protection: Single rack   Something to get down with

climbs.name: King's Gambit
climbs.fa: Dakota Walz, James Menez, & Jean François May 2015

content.description: King's Gambit has a couple punchy moves off the ground along a right leaning feature that doesn't provide much (any?) protection. Following the feature more or less straight up chasing whatever gear you can. This was done on-sight and ground up. We must have left a sling at the top to get down or hiked off. Definitely no bolts added though. Potential sport climbs around and through it may be more worthy.
content.protection: Single rack   Something to get down

content.description: Crown Cliffs is a quiet out cropping of limestone along one of the many arms of Truman Lake. Access can be made legally on foot (consult your GIS map) and is obviously quite easy by boat. The band of stone itself is about a tenth of a mile long with varying height and rock quality (think of the Warsaw crag, but before decades worth of choss was cleaned up).Two lines were put up in 2015 and beyond that I have no knowledge of any other activity. There is potential for many, many more routes though the quality of which is yet to be determined.
